    # Edward de Jong 2019-06-08 00:27 #
    And please vote your preference for the data type pattern or regexp. If you allow a value to be a regular expression (which uses a novel syntax), should the data type be called regexp or pattern? Pattern seems friendlier, but it bumps into people's expectations that a pattern might be a bitmap.
    1 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-06-08 00:26 #
    Please vote your preference: should a designator type in the language be called a path or ptr? In some sense in a graph database world, you start with a root node, and proceed through refinement to a location via subscripting or field names, so g.players[3].health is the path to a value, traditionally it was called a pointer. So which should it be, path or ptr?

    # nicolas decoster 2019-05-19 05:41 #
    Yes, I like how you set the point of vue on the programming experience first! For me it is the starting point for proposing new tool/language for programming. And I like the way you focus on the hierarchy of intents.
    # Adrian Sieber 2019-05-19 02:36 #
    =====
    Another thought on this topic:
    There is a hierarchy of code interaction with decreasing frequency:

    1. Reading
    2. Patches (e.g. change a string)
    3. Minor changes (e.g. write a function)
    4. Major changes (e.g. restructure code)
    5. Create a new project

    And I think code editors should be optimized for this interaction pattern.
    # Adrian Sieber 2019-05-19 02:27 #
    I probably should also open source the project. Let me know if you're interested in it. I'll have to clean it up a little first :sweat_smile:
    # Adrian Sieber 2019-05-19 02:26 #
    Hi folks!

    I developed following webapp a few years ago and although I was (and still am) quite excited about the possibilities, I never released it. I couldn't imagine the programming community at large get excited about it. Also I was sick of preaching things nobody else seems to care about.

    But now that I discovered this community, maybe a few of you might like it:

    https://syvis.surge.sh/ErZoPhsMTcDvGT9pZswo/
    Feel free to try it out with other JavaScript code. It completely runs in your Browser!

    My thought process was that -- despite their flaws -- text editors are a quite powerful input method once you mastered the keyboard.
    Consuming / investigating code in a text editor, however, not so. Our syntax highlighting, code style guides, indentation based code, etc. are just a desperate attempt to mitigate this.

    What if coding was more like writing a LaTeX paper? The LaTeX code is good to build the document, and for reviewing and distributing it, the rendered PDF is much better suited.

    Next steps could be:

    - Custom themes, so that you can render the code to you liking
    - Enable interactive editing for minor things like changing a number or a string, reordering parts, …

    Here is another abstract from a slightly different angle:

    In most programming languages
    the semantic meaning of a program is disconnected from
    the formatting of the code and the naming of variables and keywords.
    This means semantically equivalent code can be written in a vastly
    different textual representations.
    This poses problems in terms of readability and understandability
    of code.
    Even minor modifications of punctuation or formatting in comparison to
    a developers familiar style can drastically decrease the performance.
    In order to mitigate these problems I propose to visualize code
    in a graphical and deterministic way.
    Instead of relying on the author of the code to format it in a acceptable
    manner, each developer can choose a visualization of their liking.
    This has the potential to decrease the error rate and
    increase the development speed of programmers.

    Looking foward to you feedback! :grin:
    11 comments
    # Rafael Luque 2019-05-14 10:44 #

    # Corey Montella 2019-05-02 17:45 #
    Hi everyone. I've made some progress on Mech documentation I wanted to share here. Mostly I've done work on the rendering of Mech documents, so I've just started with writing the actual documentation. It's rough and incomplete now, but I was hoping for some feedback on the docs layout.

    Here's a good example of a page that shows off most of the features:
    http://docs.mech-lang.org/#/docs/programs/blocks.mec
    Here is the raw text:
    https://gitlab.com/mech-lang/docs-page/raw/master/public/doc…

    Couple of features:
    -You can render a view under a block by writing to the block/view table. The syntax is subject to -change.
    -You can embed a Mech value in text with double square brackets. [[]]
    -You can click on any table in a block to see a table inspector with the contents rendered in a nice layout

    Here's an example of a function reference:
    http://docs.mech-lang.org/#/docs/math/sin.mec

    Here's an example of an error:
    http://docs.mech-lang.org/#/examples/error.mec

    Hoping for any feedback you might have before I go back to writing the actual documentation. Thanks!

    # Brian Hempel 2019-04-10 05:47 #
    # Kartik Agaram 2019-04-09 23:20 #
    When you say 'trace', do you mean 'backtrace' (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_trace)? It doesn't seem congruent with your definition:

    > the linking of your code’s runtime behavior to the higher level abstractions you used when writing it.

    That's just debugging information? Not as important an idea, I think.

    The word 'trace' means very different things in the JIT world, or in the microprocessor design world, or in the Lisp world.

    ---

    Lol at the vulnerability as one of the primitives of today's software. It looks like the section is mistitled and you mean "vulnerability management". But I prefer the title to the contents of that section :smile:
    1 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-04-09 20:55 #
    You mention some of the tools/techniques that have been used, but it would have been more complete and accurate if you started with the first debugging tool after tracing was the crash dump, then checkpoint/restart appeared, then breakpoint debugging, then postmortem debugging (Modula-2, via the Logitech Multiscope debugger was the first commercial tool to offer this, where you could see all the data structures and stack trace on a crashed program from a customer), then omniscient debugging which is creeping into tools, which has been popping in and out of view for the last 15 years with greater frequency.

    The exact origin of each of these tools and techniques can always be debated, but there is a clearly in our history a progression towards greater information, and omniscient debugging, (which includes time traveling features, plus data structure visualizations) are definitely going to be common in the future.

    I disagree that Docker is some kind of progress. It is merely a patch over the atrocious lack of integrity checking in the archaic dynamic linking methodology of Unix, which is 50 years old, and long past expiration date. Because you can break things terribly with a new version of a shared library, Docker creates a half-assed virtual machine that lets two program needing different versions of shared libraries run at the same time on a machine. The fact that the version conflicts exist, and that old versions of a library are not updated (leaving security holes galore) cannot be considered an acceptable long term solution.

    And if i can put on my grump-meister helmet, i frankly think that API's are the main evil of today's programming world, and must be eliminated. The future is a world of interchangeable parts, not tens of thousands of API's, which have to be called in some specific order, and have mysterious interactions.

    And version control systems which lets people break stuff constantly as they do in many open source projects have to evolve so that breakage is less common. The sad truth is that all the open source projects don't seem to have any external or built-in QA, so the code oscillates badly, with a good vintage of a project hard to pin down.
    4 comments

    7 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-03-13 00:55 #
    Swift has some really crazy complex super subtle syntax features that i can't even imagine why they bothered because they take more effort to learn than they must save. All part of the committee approach that Swift has adopted, which is the PL/1 or ADA of our time. A gigantic language that just couldn't say "no" to any feature anyone could think of. PL/1 was great, and so is Swift, but it isn't easy for other people to make a Swift compiler, so it is more or less locked-in to Apple.
    18 comments
    # Edward de Jong 2019-03-13 00:54 #
    If some language has a built-in function called flurb(), you can always just create a runtime function that does that function on the other language. But structural issues, name scoping, and tricky closures and nesting of symbols can be hard to remap between languages. As a long time user of Modula-2 i could convert M2 to many other languages very easily because it is actually very simple. Always easier to map from a simple language into a more complex one (like Swift for example), but a nightmare to go from a complex one like Swift into say Pascal or Python.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-03-13 00:51 #
    Don't get me wrong; if you can find two languages whose naming systems are similar enough it should work okay. But if you try to map a language with deeply nested naming systems into one that has far fewer levels, it gets very thorny.
    # Edward de Jong 2019-03-13 00:48 #
    The Loyc structure works okay, but where it will break down in terms of offering language translateability is that the real problem with language conversion is not the operators; those are typically fairly straightforward to parse: a + b means the + operator with two operands.The killer problem is all the symbol table gyrations that come up, with all the subtle context switches. For example, you have a static global named x, a field in a record named x, a local variable named x, and the compiler is tracking a very complex web of inheritance chains to figure out which x you mean at any one time. Your conversion program would need to disambiguate the names. In my current work more than 50% of the total effort of the compiler is tracking all the symbol information. In inferred type languages, where the programmer doesn't have to specify explicitly the type, but it is inferred through various means, it gets extremely difficult to nail down the type, but one must of course do this to remap the code. So although the goal of your project is laudable, i believe it will become impossible, else you would be implementing a compiler for each language, just to map it to another. If two languages are similar enough the mapping can go one way pretty easily but to go bidirectionally between a wide variety of languages would be a massive and quite difficult task.
    4 comments
    # Dan Cook 2019-03-12 11:38 #
    I will definitely give this a look when I have some time

    # Stathis Sideris 2019-03-04 03:21 #
    I tweeted this recently: https://twitter.com/stathissideris/status/1099322082905808896 - it’s about my efforts to query the Clojure AST using datalog from the REPL. The same system also supports querying information about the actual invocations of functions and the data that was passed to them, so eventually you’d have a hybrid static/dynamic analysis. It’s still at the proof of concept stage so I think it hasn’t realized its full potential, but I’d be interested about what you think about it.

    I've now officially given up, and the freedom is like fresh air
    # Duncan Cragg 2019-02-28 11:28 #
    I've spent my whole life trying to fit my ideas in to the constraints of what coders expect

    # Brian Hempel 2019-02-20 10:18 #
    When working on visionary systems or systems designed for experts, the academic publishing review process can sometimes be brutal. Reviewers sometimes expect user studies, but complex systems, particularly systems built for experts, cannot be compared head-to-head with prior work in 1-2hr user study sessions—fluency with a tool could require 6 months practice or more! How then do you show that the system you’ve built is actually an improvement, if you can’t perform traditional human testing on it? In 2007, Dan Olsen addressed this problem, identifying the common reviewer mistakes (“Evaluation Errors”), outlining a framework for justifying the contribution of a complex system (“STU Context”), and offering possible claims a paper could make in leu of human usability tests. To help me keep track of these ideas, I pulled them into a one-page summary. I hope others find this summary helpful as well.
    5 comments
    # Steve Krouse 2019-02-14 01:44 #

    # Humberto Ayres Pereira 2019-02-12 10:17 #
    hello :wave:

    we just launched dashdash in Public Beta (dashdash.com)! we're a new online spreadsheet where anyone can create their custom tools. you just type type regular spreadsheet functions and can get call webservices with data & APIs, and do automation, right from the cells.

    our Public Beta means we're releasing accounts and features faster now. the tool is stable enough for operating out of it.
    What I want: feedback x1000! if you are interested in automations, services and spreadsheets, please register (dashdash.com) and send me all your thoughts and ideas.

    if you want to know more about how we are structuring computation inside cells, you can read here: https://medium.com/dashdash/the-5-superpowers-of-spreadsheet-cells-2b44b1455647

    # Corey Montella 2019-02-04 19:38 #
    Hey everyone. I've been quiet for a while, but I finally have something to show for my time working on my language Mech the last couple of months. Last I showed it off here I had a video demo of a bouncing balls program. Shortly after that video I tore everything out and made a more realistic runtime. After about 4 months of work I'm back to where I was then, feature wise, but now the foundation is more stable and you can actually play with it in the browser:

    http://mech-lang.gitlab.io/try/

    Click compile and the bouncing ball program compiles. Then click start timer to set the balls in motion. You can click in the canvas area to add more balls. Click pause to stop them. Step forward and back moves through the transaction history.

    I don't really have a user guide done yet, but I have a list of expression that I know work, so you can get an idea of what's possible from this: https://gitlab.com/mech-lang/syntax/blob/master/tests/compiler.rs

    The main idea is that each block of code reads from or writes to a set of global tables, denoted by hashtags. When all the input to a block is available, that block will execute the operations defined therein, and then writes data out to the global tables with a set operator :=. Blocks re-execute every time its inputs change, providing a reactive, live feel. You can also gate a block's execution on a specific column with the ~ operator, which will cause a block to run only if the associated column changes.

    Right now, there are a ton of language features I haven't implemented yet. What I have implemented are basic math, operators, some inequality operators, logic operators, table construction syntax, and indexing operators. I'd like to make sure these operators are rock solid before I move on to anything else. I'm hoping some intrepid people here can test drive what I have now to find cases that don't work. For now, you can see program output in the Chrome console by clicking on "View Core". If you find any code that explodes or produces unexpected output, please let me know by filing an issue here: https://github.com/mech-lang/mech/issues
    14 comments

Would love to get feedback on anything that is unclear or unjustified.

    # Gregor 2019-01-27 04:38 #
    Alrighty, I need the rubber to hit the road: My editor is still in a bit of a rough shape, but I'd really appreciate getting some early feedback:
    The basic idea is having a code editor that's fairly close to the text based editors we have atm but that uses more contextual information to make every keypress more meaningful . "Every" being the eventual goal, in its current state the right word would be "Some".
    Similar to my previous project, Snytactor, it's atm only a JS editor. Supported syntax currently includes: declarations, arrays, objects, arrow functions (somewhat), function calls & if/for statements. Happy to get comments / bug reports / ideas or even PRs :upside_down_face:

    # Steve Krouse 2019-01-21 08:10 #
    As many of you know, I'm obsessed with original-Conal-Elliott FRP. It took be forever to understand it, so I've balked at trying to explain it to others.

    Last week, @Jonathan Edwards convinced me to spend some real time on an essay to explain it. I just finished draft 1. (So please don't share around on social media just yet.)

    https://futureofcoding.org/drafts/dctp

    The essay was written for people who already like ReactJS and functional programming, and maybe even have some Haskell experience.

    It's at least a 20-minute read, so give it a go when you get a chance. No rush. At this stage, I'm looking for birds-eye-view feedback. Do you follow the overall argument arc? If not, where do you fall through the cracks? Does the tone work for you or is it too informal?

    Really appreciate anyone taking the time to review and give feedback. This piece is important to me :heart:

    # Arsalan Bashir 2018-12-20 07:06 #
    Hi all, I’m building a non-linear reactive document for the masses! And it’s called “AfterClass”. AfterClass is right now is specifically for founders of early stage startups who want to save time and money by automating every day repetitive tasks connected with their documents, like sending and keeping track of invoices, or asking the team for updates and logging those in a document, or even automatically pulling data from your other apps (Google Analytics, Quickbooks, etc) and compiling a weekly report and sending it to your email.

    I like to think of it as “Zapier meets Google Docs”

    My end goal is to create a dynamic digital medium that is more tied in with the real world by means of being non-linear and reactive, as opposed to static and linear documents.

    I am aware that this is a massive problem, but here’s step one — https://afterclass.co

    I’d be happy to hear your feedback and comments

    # Joshua Horowitz 2018-11-27 00:44 #
    I just put up a video about PANE, a summer project which I presented at the LIVE workshop a few weeks ago: http://joshuahhh.com/projects/pane/. It's a prototype live, functional programming environment centered around data-visibility – all intermediate values are visible by default, and you construct a program by acting on these values. Please take a look, and let me know if you have any thoughts.

    # Aidan Cunniffe 2018-11-26 06:14 #
    Hey all -- We've gotten super focussed on using Optic to auto-document APIs and then provide autocomplete and compile-time feedback for API Requests. I think we can remove most of the friction between getting systems to communicate if systems are able to negotiate these more sophisticated contracts on their own w/o the need for humans or documentation.

    I've gotten to see a ton of backends the last month as we've been pivoting to this new use case and I stumbled upon a really interesting trend in larger codebases: there's no one way to model data types.

    One team was using Scala on the backend and they had case classes that represented each of their models, JSON Schemas for validation, MongoDB schemas to setup their tables and Play JSON schema validators that ran on the request body. On the JS frontends they had Ducktypes for each model, in Typescript they had interfaces, and on iOS they were using Swift Classes for each model. Oh and they maintain a Swagger Spec & Raml Spec which duplicates all of this again...

    That's at least 8 different representations of essentially the same information. Some of the differences affect syntax, like in JSON Schema it's type: 'string' while Ducktypes are type: String. Others are more functional -- like in MongoDB there's a notion of indices that are important for the domain of databases, but that's not important for the purposes of validating an object so folks like JSON Schema don't support it.

    Anyway they had 44 models so imagine the wasted time and headache. This whole thing came up because we were setting up Optic to read their backend and I had to ask which one of these representations was supposed to be the source of truth.

    Curious if A) you see this as a problem and B) how you might go about solving it. Hope this spawns some interesting ideas here.
    15 comments
    # Dylan Lederle-Ensign 2018-11-26 05:54 #
    http://www.dlederle.com/2018/11/25/reading-programs.html

    # Steve Krouse 2018-11-23 14:27 #
    New experiment... @Kartik Agaram and I just chatted for the first time. It was quite fun! And we recorded it! I'm curious if anyone watches it and finds value. If so, maybe we'll do it again, and maybe I'll convince others to go on the air with me in casual chats. Thanks Kartik for going out on a limb and trying this with me. Really amazing to finally chat! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DuMdDXCMDk0

    For reference on what we talked about, here are the notes I took from the convo:

    * first computer experience when he was 18
    * studying engineering in India in college
    * before he found computers, he was going to do MBA and be business guy
    * UT Austin PhD in computer systems (compiler and micro architecture)
      * wanted to re-think *all* the assumptions from the ground up based on what we know about compilers
      * as well as the other direction, redesigning compilers based on ISA architectures
      * it was all very theoretical because nobody was going to use it, because backwards-compatibility has force. who's going to invest in a new processor?
      * we're in a x86-mono culture
    * and then Bay area ever since
    * my idea of convervatism is don't change things because we don't know why they work: Chesterton's fence. You can't tear it down until you tell me why it was erected in the first place.
      * threading the needle: refactoring a legacy code base with tests and refactoring slowly, incrementalism
    * legacy is code no person on your team understands
    * he's not an IDE programmer, just a text editor guy... love how he says this outright up front
    * all the things you do to see if your code works after you right it is lost unless you encode as a test
    * joined Google in 2010 and was disheartening to see how the meat was made
    * the code at Google was shit despite great engineers, because it was passed through hands
    * law of software: suckage increases over time
    * all langauges (python 3, perl 6) go through period of backwards incompatible changes
    * big course corrections are a sign of a big mistake
    * also applies to countries: USA, Rome
      * coleen mccoulogh historical fiction novels about rome: the first man in Rome
    * but the decay in software is not entropy
      * it's more like complexity creep, which is quite similar to law creep
    * the deepness in the sky - one of his favorite sci fi books with real programmers
    * code runs on the trunk but there should be lot more forking activity....
    22 comments

    # Mariano Guerra 2018-10-29 08:35 #
    New feature, "change time travel" (undo).

    Slide through changes and see how they behave on current data.

    It can be combined with tracing and input time travel to see how it behaves on previous data.

    Any entry can be recovered and used as current.

    # David Moon 2018-09-29 23:44 #
    @David Moon has joined the channel
    # Brian Hempel 2018-09-28 13:06 #
    When I, or others, say they want to reinvent “programming,” a next thought is: how much of programming? The diversity of computational tasks is rather large. I’ve attempted to build my own diagram of the centers where human motivations and technical concerns tend to simultaneously cluster. (The central “computer” is not a cluster, but a representation of the ubiquitous cross-cutting tooling). If anyone has any knowledge of pre-existing “taxonomies” of computer science, or any thoughts on the diagram, I’d be happy to hear it.
    11 comments
    # Nick Smith 2018-09-28 03:33 #
    I'll have a read :slightly_smiling_face:. I'm using Hypothesis to make annotations and you can see them (and make them) through this link: https://hyp.is/go?url=https%3A%2F%2Fshalabh.com%2Fdrafts%2Fp…
    # Shalabh 2018-09-28 03:00 #
    Hello all, I finally (almost) finished up my 'starting perspective' and I appreciate any thoughts on this: https://shalabh.com/drafts/programmable-systems/systems-not-programs.html

    # Steve Krouse 2018-09-18 17:53 #
    Good news!! Last night I was emailed by Amjad from Repl.it about sponsoring my podcast. For starters, he’s interested in paying for transcripts of episodes, which has been widely requested. I’d be curious for thoughts about how to handle the sponsorship without being intrusive or annoying. My first thought was that somewhere in each episode I’d thank them for their sponsorship and explain in a couple of sentences what they do. Thoughts?
